title: Test Your Knowledge
body: Test your knowledge by answering the following questions.

title: Test Your Knowledge
body: Test your knowledge by answering the following questions.

title: What are the key elements to note about racial profiling?
displayTitle: What are the key elements to note about racial profiling?
body: Racial profiling is a complex term. Let’s break it down with a short quiz.

title: What does racial profiling look like?
Scenario question set 1
body:
Step 1: A flight arrives from Tehran, Iran.

It’s January and the flight had been delayed due to poor weather conditions. The passengers will need to be processed efficiently as you just handled a full flight from Stockholm, Sweden and another from Lagos, Nigeria is about to land.

CHECK: What is important at this stage? Select the reflection question that best matches the BSO responsibility.

title: What forms can unconscious bias take?
How can we identify racial profiling?
Scenario question set 2
body:
Step 2: A group of six people ranging from children to seniors are next in line.

The woman and older travellers are wearing symbols and clothing indicating that they are Muslim. You notice that the younger couple and children are holding Canadian passports; the older couple seem to have passports of a different colour. The younger woman in the group approaches you to present the passports.

CHECK: What is important at this stage? Select the reflection question that best matches the BSO responsibility.

title: Why is racial profiling training important for BSOs?
Which situations can activate our unconscious bias?
Is racial profiling an effective tool?
Scenario question set 3
body:
Step 3: You call the group of travellers up to the desk.

BSO: “Hello – Bonjour. Are you travelling all together today?”

Traveller: “Yes. With my parents and children. My parents are on their first visit to Canada – they’re coming to care for the children for a few months.”

The woman has a strong accent and you hear the older couple speaking in another language.

CHECK: What is important at this stage? Select the reflection question that best matches the BSO responsibility.

title:
Unconscious bias in practice
examples from the research
Is racial profiling the same as criminal profiling?
Scenario question set 4
body:
Step 4: The passports are in order but there’s one item that stands out to you.

As per protocol, you need to send the group for secondary examination to validate the visas of the visiting seniors.

CHECK: What is important at this stage? Select the reflection question that best matches the BSO responsibility.

title: How can unconscious bias lead to racial profiling?
What can we do to disrupt our biases?
What is our role as BSOs in preventing racial profiling?
Scenario question set 5
body:
Step 5: You hand back the Canadian passports and explain next steps.

 

BSO: “Thank you. We’ll need to ask your parents a couple of additional questions to validate their visas.”

You notice the party look somewhat anxiously at the other passports in your hand. The younger woman looks agitated.

Traveller thinks: *Not again – why am I and my family always picked out? And how embarrassing for my parents on their first visit to Canada – what are they going to think? And now everyone is looking at us.*  

Traveller: “Is this really necessary – we’re already tired after a seven-hour flight, not to mention the long line up here. I have to ask – sometimes I feel these checks are not random as either myself or my family are regularly checked for a variety of reasons when coming back to Canada. If it’s not to validate papers, it’s to check our luggage. I’d appreciate an explanation.”

CHECK: What is important at this stage? Select the reflection question that best matches the BSO responsibility.

title: How can we exercise our authority appropriately?
What is the link between race and privilege?
How can we build public confidence in our inclusive approach?
What are the impacts of racial profiling?
How can BSOs provide non-discriminatory treatment?
displayTitle: How can BSOs provide non-discriminatory treatment?
body:
NOTE: - It is acceptable to refer to an individual’s race, colour, national or ethnic origin or religion when there is a reasonable suspicion based on a multiplicity of indicators.

In carrying out our duties as BSOs, we need to be skilled in balancing these key dual responsibilities: protecting the rights of all travellers, while protecting Canada’s safety and security.

Scroll through the images to look at some areas of our job where we must apply this discretion carefully.

Click on the words listed to display questions to help guide you towards a non-discriminatory approach. Then reflect on the questions provided to guide you towards a nondiscriminatory approach.

[References: 6, 9]
